title: Simple Interest Future Value
notes: This equation calculates the future value of a principal amount under simple interest. P represents the principal amount (initial investment)

title: Simple Interest Present Value
notes: This equation calculates the present value of a future amount under simple interest. PV represents the present value (the amount that needs to be invested today)

title: Simple Interest Amount
notes: This equation calculates the interest earned or paid under simple interest. I represents the interest amount

title: Compound Interest Future Value (Annual)
notes: This equation calculates the future value with annual compounding. FV represents the future value

title: Compound Interest Future Value (Multiple Periods)
notes: This equation calculates the future value with compounding m times per year. FV represents the future value

title: Effective Annual Rate
notes: This equation calculates the effective annual interest rate from a nominal rate. EAR represents the effective annual rate

title: Continuous Compounding Future Value
notes: This equation calculates the future value with continuous compounding. FV represents the future value

title: Present Value with Annual Discounting
notes: This equation calculates the present value of a future amount with annual discounting. PV represents the present value

title: Present Value with Multiple Period Discounting
notes: This equation calculates the present value with discounting m times per year. PV represents the present value

title: Present Value with Continuous Discounting
notes: This equation calculates the present value with continuous discounting. PV represents the present value

title: Discount Factor (Annual)
notes: This equation calculates the discount factor for annual discounting. DF represents the discount factor

title: Discount Factor (Continuous)
notes: This equation calculates the discount factor with continuous compounding. DF represents the discount factor

title: Day Count Fraction (Actual/Actual)
equation_latex: t = Days in Period / Days in Year
notes: This equation calculates the time fraction using the Actual/Actual day count convention. t represents the time fraction

title: Day Count Fraction (30/360)
notes: This equation calculates the time fraction using the 30/360 day count convention. t represents the time fraction

title: Day Count Fraction (Actual/360)
notes: This equation calculates the time fraction using the Actual/360 day count convention. t represents the time fraction

title: Day Count Fraction (Actual/365)
notes: This equation calculates the time fraction using the Actual/365 day count convention. t represents the time fraction

title: Forward Rate (Discrete)
notes: Foundations - Interest Rate Conventions

title: Forward Rate (Continuous)
notes: Foundations - Interest Rate Conventions

title: Spot Rate from Zero-Coupon Bond
notes: This equation calculates the continuously compounded spot rate from a zero-coupon bond price. r_t represents the spot rate for maturity t

title: Zero-Coupon Bond Price
notes: This equation calculates the price of a zero-coupon bond given the continuously compounded spot rate. P_t represents the bond price

title: Par Yield
notes: This equation calculates the par yield (coupon rate that makes a bond price equal to par). c represents the par yield

title: Annuity Present Value
notes: This equation calculates the present value of an ordinary annuity. PV represents the present value

title: Annuity Future Value
notes: This equation calculates the future value of an ordinary annuity. FV represents the future value

title: Growing Annuity Present Value
notes: This equation calculates the present value of a growing annuity. PV represents the present value

title: Perpetuity Present Value
notes: This equation calculates the present value of a perpetuity (infinite series of equal payments). PV represents the present value

title: Growing Perpetuity Present Value
notes: This equation calculates the present value of a growing perpetuity. PV represents the present value

title: Nominal to Effective Rate Conversion
notes: This equation converts a nominal interest rate to an effective rate. r_eff represents the effective annual rate

title: Effective to Nominal Rate Conversion
notes: This equation converts an effective interest rate to a nominal rate. r_nom represents the nominal annual rate

title: Continuous Rate from Discrete
notes: This equation converts a discretely compounded rate to a continuously compounded rate. r_cont represents the continuously compounded rate

title: Discrete Rate from Continuous
notes: This equation converts a continuously compounded rate to a discretely compounded rate. r_disc represents the discretely compounded nominal rate

title: Time Value of Money General Formula
notes: This is the fundamental time value of money equation. FV represents the future value

title: Present Value of Uneven Cash Flows
notes: This equation calculates the present value of a series of unequal cash flows. PV represents the present value

title: Future Value of Uneven Cash Flows
notes: This equation calculates the future value of a series of unequal cash flows. FV represents the future value at time n

title: Interest Rate Parity
notes: This equation expresses the relationship between spot and forward exchange rates. F represents the forward exchange rate

title: Real Interest Rate
notes: This equation calculates the real interest rate from the nominal rate and inflation. r_real represents the real interest rate

title: Fisher Equation
notes: This is the exact Fisher equation relating nominal and real interest rates. r_nom represents the nominal rate

title: Yield to First Call
notes: This equation calculates the yield to call for a callable bond. YTC represents the yield to call

title: Current Yield
notes: This equation calculates the current yield of a bond. CY represents the current yield

title: Yield to Maturity Approximation
notes: This equation provides an approximation of the yield to maturity. YTM represents the yield to maturity

title: Macaulay Duration (Zero-Coupon)
notes: This equation shows that the Macaulay duration of a zero-coupon bond equals its time to maturity. D_mac represents the Macaulay duration

title: Macaulay Duration (Coupon Bond)
notes: This equation calculates the Macaulay duration of a coupon bond. D_mac represents the Macaulay duration

title: Modified Duration
notes: This equation calculates the modified duration from Macaulay duration. D_mod represents the modified duration

title: Dollar Duration
notes: This equation calculates the dollar duration (also called price value of a basis point or PV01). DD represents the dollar duration

title: Convexity
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a bond. Conv represents convexity

title: Price Change Approximation
notes: This equation approximates the percentage price change of a bond for a small change in yield. dP/P represents the percentage price change

title: Forward Price of an Asset
notes: This equation calculates the forward price of an asset with continuous dividend yield. F represents the forward price

title: Cost of Carry
notes: This equation calculates the cost of carry for an asset. C represents the cost of carry

title: Interest Rate Forward Price
notes: This equation calculates the forward interest rate using discrete compounding. F represents the forward rate

title: Zero Rate from Forward Rates
notes: i}

title: Bootstrap Method
notes: This equation is used in the bootstrap method to extract zero-coupon prices from coupon bond prices. P_T represents the zero-coupon price for maturity T

title: Rolling Down the Yield Curve
notes: This equation decomposes the total return of a bond into income and rolldown components. Total Return is the total return over a period

title: Zero-Coupon Bond Price
notes: This equation calculates the price of a zero-coupon bond. P represents the bond price

title: Zero-Coupon Bond Price (Continuous)
notes: This equation calculates the price of a zero-coupon bond using continuous compounding. P represents the bond price

title: Coupon Bond Price
notes: This equation calculates the price of a coupon bond. P represents the bond price

title: Coupon Bond Price (Annual)
notes: This equation calculates the price of an annual coupon bond using the annuity formula. P represents the bond price

title: Coupon Bond Price (Semi-Annual)
notes: This equation calculates the price of a semi-annual coupon bond. P represents the bond price

title: Bond Price Between Coupon Dates
notes: This equation calculates the bond price between coupon dates

title: Accrued Interest
equation_latex: AI = C * (Days since last coupon / Days in coupon period)
notes: This equation calculates the accrued interest on a bond between coupon dates. AI represents the accrued interest

title: Dirty Price
notes: This equation expresses the relationship between dirty price and clean price. DP represents the dirty price (full price)

title: Yield to Maturity (Zero-Coupon)
notes: This equation calculates the yield to maturity for a zero-coupon bond. y represents the yield to maturity as a decimal

title: Yield to Maturity (Coupon Bond)
notes: This equation defines the yield to maturity for a coupon bond. y represents the yield to maturity that equates the present value of all cash flows to the current price P. The YTM for coupon bonds must be solved numerically (e.g.

title: Current Yield
notes: This equation calculates the current yield of a bond. CY represents the current yield

title: Yield to Call (First Call)
notes: This equation calculates the yield to call for a callable bond. y_{tc} represents the yield to call

title: Yield to Worst
notes: YTC_2

title: Zero-Coupon Yield Curve
notes: This equation extracts the zero-coupon yield curve from zero-coupon bond prices. r_t represents the continuously compounded zero rate for maturity t

title: Par Yield
notes: This equation calculates the par yield from zero-coupon discount factors. y_par represents the par yield (coupon rate that prices the bond at par)

title: Forward Rate from Spot Rates
notes: Fixed Income - Yield Curve Analysis

title: Forward Rate (Continuous)
notes: Fixed Income - Yield Curve Analysis

title: Instantaneous Forward Rate
notes: This equation defines the instantaneous forward rate. f(t) represents the instantaneous forward rate for time t

title: Spot Rate from Forward Rates
notes: Fixed Income - Yield Curve Analysis

title: Nelson-Siegel Yield Curve
equation_latex: y(t) = beta_0 + beta_1 * (1 - e^{-t/tau})/(t/tau) + beta_2 * ((1 - e^{-t/tau})/(t/tau) - e^{-t/tau})
notes: This is the Nelson-Siegel parameterization of the yield curve. y(t) represents the yield at time t

title: Nelson-Siegel-Svensson Extension
notes: This is the Nelson-Siegel-Svensson extension with an additional hump term. y(t) represents the yield at time t

title: Yield Curve Steepness
notes: This equation measures the steepness of the yield curve. Slope represents the difference between the 10-year yield and the 2-year yield. A positive slope indicates an upward-sloping yield curve (normal)

title: Yield Curve Curvature
notes: This equation measures the curvature (hump) of the yield curve. Curvature captures the non-linearity of the yield curve shape. A positive curvature indicates a hump-shaped yield curve

title: Butterfly Spread
notes: This equation calculates the butterfly spread of the yield curve. Butterfly measures the deviation of the intermediate yield from the average of the short and long yields. It's a key measure for yield curve strategies and relative value analysis.

title: Macaulay Duration
notes: This equation calculates the Macaulay duration of a bond. D_mac represents the Macaulay duration

title: Macaulay Duration (Zero-Coupon)
notes: This equation shows that the Macaulay duration of a zero-coupon bond equals its time to maturity. D_mac represents the Macaulay duration

title: Macaulay Duration (Perpetuity)
notes: This equation calculates the Macaulay duration of a perpetuity. D_mac represents the Macaulay duration

title: Modified Duration
notes: This equation calculates the modified duration from Macaulay duration. D_mod represents the modified duration

title: Modified Duration (Approximation)
notes: This equation approximates modified duration using finite differences. D_mod represents the modified duration

title: Dollar Duration
notes: This equation calculates the dollar duration (also called PV01 or DV01). DD represents the dollar duration

title: Price Value of a Basis Point
notes: This equation calculates the price value of a basis point (PV01). PV01 represents the price change for a 1 basis point (0.01%) change in yield. PV01 is a standard risk measure used in fixed income markets and is equivalent to dollar duration scaled by 0.0001.

title: Effective Duration
notes: This equation calculates the effective duration for bonds with embedded options. D_eff represents the effective duration

title: Key Rate Duration
equation_latex: KRD_i = -(P(y + dy_i) - P(y - dy_i)) / (2 * P * dy_i)
notes: This equation calculates the key rate duration for a specific key rate. KRD_i represents the key rate duration for key rate i

title: Convexity
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a bond. Conv represents convexity

title: Convexity (Zero-Coupon)
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a zero-coupon bond. Conv represents the convexity

title: Convexity (Perpetuity)
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a perpetuity. Conv represents the convexity

title: Effective Convexity
notes: This equation calculates the effective convexity for bonds with embedded options. Conv_eff represents the effective convexity

title: Dollar Convexity
notes: This equation calculates the dollar convexity. DC represents the dollar convexity

title: Price Change Approximation
notes: This equation approximates the percentage price change of a bond for a small change in yield. dP/P represents the percentage price change

title: Taylor Series Expansion
notes: This is the Taylor series expansion of bond price with respect to yield. P(y + dy) is the new price

title: Bond Portfolio Duration
notes: This equation calculates the duration of a bond portfolio. D_port represents the portfolio duration

title: Bond Portfolio Convexity
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a bond portfolio. Conv_port represents the portfolio convexity

title: Immunization Condition 1
notes: This is the first immunization condition for matching asset and liability durations. D_A represents the duration of assets

title: Immunization Condition 2
notes: This is the second immunization condition. Conv_A represents the convexity of assets

title: Reinvestment Risk
notes: This equation calculates the reinvestment risk of a bond. R_reinv represents the reinvestment risk

title: Price Risk
notes: This equation calculates the price risk of a bond. R_price represents the price risk

title: Total Bond Risk
notes: This equation calculates the total bond risk. R_total represents the total risk

title: Spread Duration
equation_latex: D_spread = -(P(y + dy + ds) - P(y + dy - ds)) / (2 * P * ds)
notes: This equation calculates the spread duration

title: Yield Beta
notes: This equation calculates the yield beta of a bond relative to a benchmark. beta represents the yield beta

title: Information Ratio
notes: This equation calculates the information ratio of a bond portfolio. IR represents the information ratio

title: Call Option Payoff at Expiration
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals

title: Put Option Payoff at Expiration
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals

title: Call Option Profit at Expiration
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals

title: Put Option Profit at Expiration
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals

title: Intrinsic Value (Call)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals

title: Intrinsic Value (Put)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals

title: Time Value
notes: This equation calculates the time value of an option. TV represents the time value

title: Put-Call Parity
notes: This is the fundamental put-call parity relationship for European options on non-dividend paying stocks. C represents the call price

title: Put-Call Parity with Dividends
equation_latex: C + K * e^{-rT} = P + S_0 * e^{-qT}
notes: This is the put-call parity for European options on dividend-paying stocks. The terms are the same as basic put-call parity

title: Lower Bound for European Call
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals

title: Lower Bound for European Put
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals

title: Upper Bound for European Call
notes: This equation gives the upper bound for a European call option price. C represents the call price

title: Upper Bound for European Put
notes: This equation gives the upper bound for a European put option price. P represents the put price

title: American Call on Non-Dividend Stock
notes: This equation states that for American calls on non-dividend paying stocks

title: American Put on Non-Dividend Stock
notes: This equation states that American puts can be worth more than European puts. P_American represents the American put price

title: Black-Scholes Call Formula
notes: This is the famous Black-Scholes formula for pricing a European call option. C represents the call price

title: Black-Scholes Put Formula
notes: This is the Black-Scholes formula for pricing a European put option. P represents the put price

title: Black-Scholes d_1
notes: This equation defines the d_1 parameter in the Black-Scholes formula. d_1 combines the moneyness of the option (ln(S_0/K))

title: Black-Scholes d_2
notes: This equation defines the d_2 parameter in the Black-Scholes formula. d_2 is simply d_1 minus sigma * sqrt(T). d_2 represents the probability that the option will be in the money at expiration under the risk-neutral measure.

title: Black-Scholes with Dividends
notes: This is the Black-Scholes formula for a European call on a dividend-paying stock. The stock price S_0 is discounted by the continuous dividend yield q using e^{-qT}. This adjustment accounts for the expected dividend payments during the option's life.

title: Black-Scholes d_1 with Dividends
notes: This equation defines d_1 for dividend-paying stocks. The dividend yield q is subtracted from r in the numerator

title: Delta (Call)
notes: This equation calculates the delta of a European call option. Delta_C represents the call delta

title: Delta (Put)
notes: This equation calculates the delta of a European put option. Delta_P represents the put delta. For puts

title: Gamma
notes: This equation calculates the gamma of a European option (same for calls and puts). Gamma represents the second derivative of the option price with respect to the underlying price. It measures the rate of change of delta and is highest for at-the-money options near expiration.

title: Normal PDF
notes: This is the probability density function of the standard normal distribution. N'(x) represents the PDF value at x

title: Theta (Call)
equation_latex: Theta_C = -(S_0 * N'(d_1) * sigma) / (2 * sqrt(T)) - r * K * e^{-rT} * N(d_2)
notes: This equation calculates the theta of a European call option. Theta_C represents the call theta

title: Theta (Put)
equation_latex: Theta_P = -(S_0 * N'(d_1) * sigma) / (2 * sqrt(T)) + r * K * e^{-rT} * N(-d_2)
notes: This equation calculates the theta of a European put option. Theta_P represents the put theta. Unlike calls

title: Vega
notes: This equation calculates the vega of a European option (same for calls and puts). Vega represents the sensitivity of the option price to changes in volatility. Vega is always positive

title: Rho (Call)
notes: This equation calculates the rho of a European call option. Rho_C represents the call rho

title: Rho (Put)
notes: This equation calculates the rho of a European put option. Rho_P represents the put rho. For puts

title: Vanna
notes: This equation calculates the vanna of a European option. Vanna represents the sensitivity of delta to changes in volatility

title: Charm
equation_latex: Charm = -N'(d_1) * (2rT - d_2 * sigma * sqrt(T)) / (2T * sigma * sqrt(T))
notes: This equation calculates the charm of a European option. Charm represents the sensitivity of delta to changes in time (delta decay). Charm is important for understanding how delta changes as expiration approaches.

title: Vomma
equation_latex: Vomma = S_0 * N'(d_1) * sqrt(T) * d_1 * d_2 / sigma
notes: This equation calculates the vomma (also called volga) of a European option. Vomma represents the sensitivity of vega to changes in volatility. Vomma is positive for most options

title: Veta
equation_latex: Veta = S_0 * N'(d_1) * sqrt(T) * (r * q + (d_1 * d_2 * sigma) / (2T))
notes: This equation calculates the veta of a European option. Veta represents the sensitivity of vega to changes in time (vega decay). Veta helps understand how volatility sensitivity changes as expiration approaches.

title: Speed
notes: This equation calculates the speed of a European option. Speed represents the third derivative of the option price with respect to the underlying price. Speed measures the rate of change of gamma and is important for understanding convexity risk.

title: Color
equation_latex: Color = -N'(d_1) / (2 * S_0 * T * sigma * sqrt(T)) * (1 + (2rT - d_2 * sigma * sqrt(T)) / (2T))
notes: This equation calculates the color of a European option. Color represents the sensitivity of gamma to changes in time (gamma decay). Color helps understand how the curvature of the option price changes as expiration approaches.

title: Zomma
notes: This equation calculates the zomma of a European option. Zomma represents the sensitivity of gamma to changes in volatility. Zomma is important for managing volatility risk in gamma-sensitive portfolios.

title: Implied Volatility (Definition)
notes: T

title: Newton-Raphson for Implied Volatility
notes: This equation implements the Newton-Raphson method to solve for implied volatility. sigma_n is the current guess

title: Volatility Smile
notes: Equity Derivatives - Black-Scholes-Merton

title: Volatility Skew
notes: This equation measures the volatility skew. Skew represents the slope of implied volatility across strike prices. sigma_imp(K_25) and sigma_imp(K_75) are the implied volatilities for 25-delta and 75-delta options respectively. Negative skew is common in equity markets.

title: Volatility Surface
notes: Equity Derivatives - Black-Scholes-Merton

title: Asian Option (Arithmetic Average)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options

title: Asian Option (Geometric Average)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options

title: Asian Option Price (Geometric)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options

title: Barrier Option (Up-and-Out Call)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options

title: Barrier Option (Down-and-In Put)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options

title: Lookback Option (Floating Strike Call)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options

title: Lookback Option (Fixed Strike Call)
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options

title: Binary Option (Cash-or-Nothing Call)
equation_latex: Payoff = C if S_T > K else 0
notes: This equation gives the payoff of a cash-or-nothing binary call option. The option pays a fixed cash amount C if the underlying price exceeds the strike at expiration

title: Binary Option (Asset-or-Nothing Call)
equation_latex: Payoff = S_T if S_T > K else 0
notes: This equation gives the payoff of an asset-or-nothing binary call option. The option pays the underlying asset price if it exceeds the strike at expiration

title: Exchange Option
notes: T

title: Spread Option
notes: T - K

title: Forward Start Option
notes: This equation prices a forward start option that begins at time T_1 and expires at T_2. The option starts at-the-money forward. Forward start options are used in employee stock option plans.

title: Bermudan Option
notes: This equation states that Bermudan options (exercisable on specified dates) are at least as valuable as European options (exercisable only at expiration). C_Bermudan represents the Bermudan option price

title: Digital Option Price
notes: This equation prices a cash-or-nothing digital call option. C represents the option price

title: Gap Option Payoff
equation_latex: Payoff = S_T - K_2 if S_T > K_1 else 0
notes: This equation gives the payoff of a gap call option. The option has two strike prices: K_1 triggers exercise

title: Power Option Payoff
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options

title: Quanto Option
notes: Equity Derivatives - Exotic Options

title: Asian Option Delta Approximation
notes: This equation approximates the delta of an arithmetic Asian option. The delta depends on the relationship between the current price and the prices at which the average is calculated. This approximation is used because there's no closed-form formula.

title: Option Elasticity
notes: This equation calculates the elasticity of an option. Elasticity represents the percentage change in option price for a 1% change in the underlying price. For calls

title: Leverage
notes: This equation calculates the leverage of an option position. Leverage represents how many shares of underlying you effectively control with one option. Deep in-the-money options have leverage close to 1

title: Option Beta
notes: This equation relates option beta to underlying beta. Beta_option represents the option's beta (sensitivity to market returns)

title: Probability of ITM (Call)
notes: This equation calculates the risk-neutral probability that a call option expires in the money. The probability is N(d_2)

title: Probability of ITM (Put)
notes: This equation calculates the risk-neutral probability that a put option expires in the money. The probability is N(-d_2). This probability is used in option pricing and risk management.

title: Expected Terminal Stock Price
notes: This equation gives the expected terminal stock price under the risk-neutral measure. E[S_T] represents the expectation

title: Option Value Decomposition
notes: This equation decomposes an option's value into intrinsic and time components. C represents the total option value. Intrinsic value is the immediate exercise value

title: Early Exercise Premium (American Put)
notes: This equation calculates the early exercise premium for an American put option. EEP represents the extra value from the early exercise right. This premium is positive for deep in-the-money puts on non-dividend stocks.

title: Optimal Exercise Boundary (American Put)
notes: q

title: Option Theta Decay
notes: This equation approximates the theta decay near expiration. The dominant term is the volatility term

title: Gamma Scalping Profit
notes: This equation estimates the profit from gamma scalping (delta-hedging). The gamma term captures profit from convexity when the underlying moves

title: Delta Hedging Error
notes: This equation estimates the hedging error from discrete delta hedging. The error comes from the convexity (gamma) of the option price. More frequent rebalancing reduces this error but increases transaction costs.

title: Option Implied Distribution
equation_latex: f(S_T) = (1 / (S_T * sigma * sqrt(2 * pi * T))) * exp(-(ln(S_T/S_0) - (r - 0.5 * sigma^2) * T)^2 / (2 * sigma^2 * T))
notes: This equation gives the risk-neutral probability density function of the terminal stock price under Black-Scholes assumptions. f(S_T) represents the lognormal distribution

title: Risk-Neutral Valuation
notes: Equity Derivatives - Black-Scholes-Merton

title: Martingale Property
notes: This equation expresses the martingale property of discounted stock prices under the risk-neutral measure. S_t represents the stock price at time t

title: Change of Numeraire
notes: This is the Black-Scholes formula expressed using the change of numeraire technique. The first term uses the stock as numeraire

title: Option Price as Integral
equation_latex: C = e^{-rT} * integral_K^inf (S_T - K) * f(S_T) dS_T
notes: This equation expresses the option price as an integral over the terminal stock price. C represents the call price

title: Interest Rate Swap Fixed Leg
notes: This equation calculates the present value of the fixed leg of an interest rate swap. PV_fixed represents the present value

title: Interest Rate Swap Floating Leg
notes: Fixed Income Derivatives - Interest Rate Swaps

title: Swap Value at Inception
notes: This equation calculates the value of a swap at inception. V_swap represents the swap value

title: Par Swap Rate
notes: This equation calculates the par swap rate (the fixed rate that makes the swap value zero at inception). R_swap represents the par swap rate

title: Swap Value After Inception
notes: This equation calculates the value of an existing swap. V_swap represents the current swap value

title: Swap DV01
equation_latex: DV01_swap = sum_{i=1}^n (delta_i * DF_i * N) - sum_{i=1}^n (delta_i * DF_i * N)
notes: This equation calculates the DV01 (dollar value of a 01 basis point change) of a swap. DV01_swap represents the sensitivity of the swap value to a 1 bp change in rates. For a par swap

title: Swap Duration
equation_latex: D_swap = (sum_{i=1}^n t_i * delta_i * DF_i) / (sum_{i=1}^n delta_i * DF_i)
notes: This equation calculates the duration of a swap. D_swap represents the swap duration

title: Swap Convexity
equation_latex: Conv_swap = (sum_{i=1}^n t_i^2 * delta_i * DF_i) / (sum_{i=1}^n delta_i * DF_i)
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a swap. Conv_swap represents the swap convexity

title: Forward Rate Agreement Payoff
notes: This equation gives the payoff of a Forward Rate Agreement (FRA). Payoff represents the FRA payoff

title: Swap Spread
notes: This equation calculates the swap spread. Spread represents the difference between the swap rate and the treasury rate of the same maturity. The swap spread reflects credit risk and liquidity differences between the swap market and the treasury market.

title: Cross-Currency Swap
notes: Fixed Income Derivatives - Interest Rate Swaps

title: Cross-Currency Swap FX Leg
equation_latex: PV_foreign = X_0 * sum_{i=1}^n (N_foreign * R_foreign * delta_i * DF_foreign
notes: Fixed Income Derivatives - Interest Rate Swaps

title: Cross-Currency Swap Value
notes: This equation calculates the value of a cross-currency swap. V_ccs represents the swap value

title: Asset Swap
notes: This equation calculates the asset swap spread. Spread represents the spread that makes the bond price equal to par when combined with an interest rate swap. Asset swaps are used to convert fixed-rate bonds to floating-rate exposure.

title: Total Return Swap
equation_latex: Payoff = (Bond Return + Coupon - LIBOR - Spread) * N
notes: This equation gives the payoff of a total return swap. Payoff represents the periodic payment

title: Inflation Swap
notes: This equation gives the payoff of an inflation swap. Payoff represents the periodic payment

title: Amortizing Swap
notes: This equation calculates the present value of an amortizing swap. PV represents the present value

title: Accreting Swap
notes: This equation calculates the present value of an accreting swap. PV represents the present value

title: Forward Swap Rate
notes: This equation calculates the forward swap rate for a swap starting at time t and ending at time T. F_swap represents the forward swap rate

title: Caplet Payoff
notes: Fixed Income Derivatives - Interest Rate Options

title: Cap Price
notes: This equation calculates the price of a cap as the sum of caplet prices. C represents the cap price

title: Caplet Price (Black Model)
equation_latex: Caplet = N * delta * DF * [F * N(d_1) - K * N(d_2)]
notes: This equation prices a caplet using the Black model. Caplet represents the caplet price

title: Black Model d_1
notes: This equation defines the d_1 parameter in the Black model for interest rate options. d_1 combines the moneyness (ln(F/K))

title: Black Model d_2
notes: This equation defines the d_2 parameter in the Black model. d_2 is simply d_1 minus sigma * sqrt(T). d_2 represents the probability that the option will be in the money under the forward measure.

title: Floorlet Payoff

title: Floor Price

title: Probability of Default
notes: This equation defines the probability of default. PD represents the probability that a borrower will default within a specified time period T. PD is a fundamental credit risk metric used in pricing credit derivatives and calculating credit risk capital requirements.

title: Cumulative Default Probability
notes: This equation calculates the cumulative probability of default assuming constant hazard rate. CDP(T) represents the cumulative default probability by time T

title: Hazard Rate
notes: This equation calculates the hazard rate from the probability of default. lambda represents the hazard rate

title: Survival Probability
notes: This equation calculates the survival probability (probability of no default). Q(T) represents the probability of surviving to time T without default

title: Loss Given Default
notes: This equation calculates the loss given default. LGD represents the percentage loss incurred if default occurs

title: Exposure at Default
notes: This equation calculates the exposure at default. EAD represents the amount owed to the lender at the time of default

title: Expected Loss
notes: This equation calculates the expected loss from credit exposure. EL represents the expected loss

title: Unexpected Loss
notes: This equation calculates the unexpected loss (standard deviation of loss). UL represents the unexpected loss

title: Credit VaR
notes: This equation calculates the credit Value at Risk. Credit VaR represents the loss at a given confidence level

title: Merton Model
notes: sigma_A

title: Merton Default Probability
notes: This equation calculates the default probability under the Merton model. PD represents the default probability

title: Distance to Default
notes: This equation calculates the distance to default under the Merton model. DD represents the number of standard deviations the firm value is from the default threshold. Higher DD indicates lower default probability.

title: Credit Spread
notes: This equation calculates the credit spread from survival probability. s represents the credit spread

title: Intensity-Based Spread
notes: This equation approximates the credit spread using hazard rate and loss given default. s represents the credit spread

title: CDS Spread
notes: This equation approximates the CDS spread under constant hazard rate. s_cds represents the CDS spread

title: CDS Pricing (Protection Buyer)
equation_latex: PV_premium = sum_{i=1}^n s * delta_i * Q(t_i) * DF_i
notes: This equation calculates the present value of premium payments for a CDS. PV_premium represents the PV of premiums

title: CDS Pricing (Protection Seller)

notes: This equation calculates the present value of default leg payments. PV_default represents the PV of default payments

title: CDS Par Spread

title: CDS Value
notes: This equation calculates the value of an existing CDS. V_cds represents the CDS value

title: CDS Delta
notes: This equation calculates the delta of a CDS. Delta_cds represents the sensitivity to the survival probability

title: CDS DV01
notes: This equation calculates the DV01 of a CDS. DV01_cds represents the sensitivity to interest rate changes

title: Upfront Payment
notes: This equation calculates the upfront payment for a CDS. UP represents the upfront payment

notes: This equation calculates the spread of a CDS index. s_index represents the index spread

title: Tranche Attachment Point
notes: This equation calculates the attachment point of a CDO tranche. AP represents the attachment point (percentage of portfolio losses that must occur before the tranche suffers losses)

title: Tranche Detachment Point
notes: This equation calculates the detachment point of a CDO tranche. DP represents the detachment point (percentage of portfolio losses that wipe out the tranche)

title: Expected Tranche Loss

title: Tranche Spread

notes: This equation defines the credit migration probability. P_ij represents the probability that an obligor migrates from rating i to rating j over a given time period. Migration matrices are used in multi-period credit risk models.

title: Markov Chain Credit Model

title: Credit Rating Migration

notes: This is the Vasicek one-factor model for portfolio credit risk. L_i represents the default indicator for obligor i

title: Asymptotic Single-Risk Factor

notes: This equation gives the conditional default probability under the ASRF framework. PD_i represents the conditional PD for obligor i

title: Credit VaR under ASRF
equation_latex: Credit VaR = LGD * EAD * (N((N^{-1}(PD) + sqrt(rho) * N^{-1}(0.999)) / sqrt(1 - rho)) - PD)
notes: This equation calculates the 99.9% credit VaR under the ASRF model. Credit VaR represents the unexpected loss at the 99.9% confidence level

notes: This equation calculates the expected return of a portfolio. E[R] represents the portfolio expected return

title: Tracking Error
notes: This equation calculates the tracking error of a portfolio relative to a benchmark. sigma_tracking represents the standard deviation of the difference between portfolio return R_p and benchmark return R_b. Tracking error measures how closely the portfolio follows its benchmark.

notes: This equation defines the Capital Allocation Line (CAL). R_p represents the return of a portfolio on the CAL

title: Efficient Frontier Optimization
equation_latex: min sigma^2_p subject to E[R_p] = target_return and sum w_i = 1
notes: This equation defines the mean-variance optimization problem for finding the efficient frontier. The objective is to minimize portfolio variance subject to achieving a target return and the weights summing to 1. The efficient frontier contains all optimal portfolios.

title: Minimum Variance Portfolio
notes: This equation calculates the weights of the global minimum variance portfolio. w_mvp represents the portfolio weights

title: Tangency Portfolio
notes: This equation calculates the weights of the tangency portfolio (maximum Sharpe ratio portfolio). w_tan represents the portfolio weights

title: Expected Shortfall (CVaR)
notes: This equation calculates Expected Shortfall (also called Conditional VaR or CVaR). ES_alpha represents the expected loss given that the loss exceeds VaR_alpha. ES is a coherent risk measure that considers tail risk beyond VaR.

title: Expected Shortfall (Normal)
notes: This equation calculates ES under the normal distribution. ES_alpha represents the expected shortfall

title: Incremental VaR
notes: This equation calculates the incremental VaR of an asset. IVaR_i represents the change in portfolio VaR when asset i is removed. Incremental VaR helps identify which assets contribute most to portfolio risk. Positive IVaR means the asset increases risk.

title: Marginal VaR
notes: Portfolio Theory and Risk Management - Risk Metrics

notes: This equation calculates the component VaR of an asset. CVaR_i represents the contribution of asset i to total portfolio VaR

title: Maximum Drawdown
notes: This equation calculates the maximum drawdown of a portfolio. MDD represents the largest peak-to-trough decline

title: Average Drawdown
notes: This equation calculates the average drawdown of a portfolio. ADD represents the average of all drawdowns over the period. Average drawdown complements maximum drawdown by providing information about typical loss severity.

title: Calmar Ratio

title: Ito's Lemma

title: Ito's Lemma for GBM
equation_latex: d ln(S_t) = (mu - 0.5 * sigma^2) * dt + sigma * dW_t
notes: This is Ito's Lemma applied to ln(S_t) for GBM. d ln(S_t) represents the change in log price

title: Ito's Lemma for f(S_t) = S_t^2
equation_latex: d(S_t^2) = (2 * mu * S_t^2 + sigma^2 * S_t^2) * dt + 2 * sigma * S_t^2 * dW_t
notes: This is Ito's Lemma applied to f(S_t) = S_t^2. The drift term includes both the 2*mu*S_t^2 term from ordinary calculus and the sigma^2*S_t^2 Ito correction. This example shows how Ito's Lemma differs from the ordinary chain rule.

title: Stochastic Integral

title: Ito Isometry

notes: This equation defines the Ito Isometry property. The expectation of the squared stochastic integral equals the expectation of the integral of the squared integrand. Ito Isometry is crucial for calculating variances of stochastic integrals.

title: Martingale Property
notes: This equation shows that the stochastic integral is a martingale. The conditional expectation of the future integral given information at time t is zero. The martingale property is fundamental to risk-neutral valuation in finance.

notes: This equation defines the least squares problem in LSM. LSM estimates the coefficients b_j to minimize the squared error between discounted payoffs and basis function values. LSM is the standard method for pricing American options with Monte Carlo.

title: Newton-Raphson Method
notes: This equation defines the Newton-Raphson method for root finding. x_{n+1} represents the next approximation

title: Bisection Method
notes: This equation defines the bisection method for root finding. x_{n+1} is the midpoint of the interval [a_n

title: Implied Volatility Newton-Raphson
notes: This equation calculates implied volatility using Newton-Raphson. sigma_{n+1} is the updated volatility

title: Gradient Descent
notes: This equation defines gradient descent for optimization. x_{n+1} represents the next iterate

title: Stochastic Gradient Descent
notes: This equation defines SGD for optimization with large datasets. x_{n+1} represents the next iterate

title: Levenberg-Marquardt Algorithm
equation_latex: (J^T * J + lambda * diag(J^T * J)) * delta = J^T * (y - f(x))
notes: This equation defines the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm for nonlinear least squares. J is the Jacobian

title: Calibration Objective Function
equation_latex: min_theta sum_{i=1}^N w_i * (Model Price_i(theta) - Market Price_i)^2
notes: This equation defines the calibration objective function. The goal is to find model parameters theta that minimize the weighted sum of squared errors between model prices and market prices. Calibration is essential for making models match market data.

title: Model Risk
equation_latex: MR = |Model Price - Market Price| / Market Price
notes: This equation calculates model risk as the percentage error between model and market prices. MR represents the model risk

title: Backtesting
equation_latex: Hit Ratio = (Number of Correct Predictions) / (Total Predictions)
notes: This equation calculates the hit ratio for backtesting a model. Hit Ratio represents the proportion of correct predictions. Backtesting validates model performance on historical data and is essential for model validation.

title: Kupiec Test
equation_latex: LR = -2 * ln((1 - alpha)^{N - x} * alpha^x / ((1 - p)^{N - x} * p^x))
notes: This equation defines the Kupiec test for VaR model validation. LR is the likelihood ratio statistic

title: Christoffersen Test
notes: This equation defines the Christoffersen test for VaR model validation. LR_cc is the combined likelihood ratio

title: Bootstrap Method
equation_latex: theta* = f(X*) where X* is a bootstrap sample
notes: This equation defines the bootstrap method for estimating confidence intervals. theta* is the statistic calculated from the bootstrap sample X*

title: Jackknife Method
notes: This equation defines the jackknife method for bias and variance estimation. theta_jackknife is the jackknife estimate

title: Cross-Validation
notes: This equation defines K-fold cross-validation. CV represents the cross-validation error

title: Regularization
notes: Numerical Methods - Optimization Techniques

title: Akaike Information Criterion
notes: This equation defines the AIC for model selection. AIC represents the Akaike Information Criterion

title: Bayesian Information Criterion
notes: This equation defines the BIC for model selection. BIC represents the Bayesian Information Criterion

title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation
notes: This equation defines MLE. theta_MLE represents the parameter values that maximize the likelihood L(theta | X) given data X. MLE is a fundamental method for parameter estimation in statistical models.

title: Method of Moments
notes: This equation defines the method of moments. theta_MM represents parameters that match theoretical moments to sample moments. Method of moments is simpler than MLE but less efficient for many models.

title: Expectation-Maximization
equation_latex: E-step: Q(theta | theta^{(t)}) = E[log L(theta | X

title: Kalman Filter

title: Particle Filter
notes: This equation defines the particle filter (sequential Monte Carlo) for state estimation. weights_i are the importance weights for particle i

title: Greeks by Finite Differences
equation_latex: Delta = (f(S + delta S) - f(S - delta S)) / (2 * delta S)
notes: This equation calculates Delta using central finite differences. Delta represents the sensitivity of the option price to the underlying price. Finite differences are used when analytical Greeks are not available. Central differences are more accurate than forward/backward differences.

title: Gamma by Finite Differences
equation_latex: Gamma = (f(S + delta S) - 2 * f(S) + f(S - delta S)) / (delta S)^2
notes: This equation calculates Gamma using finite differences. Gamma represents the second derivative of the option price with respect to the underlying price. Finite difference Gamma requires three option price evaluations.

notes: This technique splits a complex PDE into simpler sub-problems that can be solved sequentially. Operator splitting is used for multi-dimensional PDEs and PDEs with mixed derivatives

title: Historical Volatility
notes: This equation calculates historical volatility from price data. sigma_hist represents the historical volatility

title: Exponentially Weighted Moving Average
notes: This equation defines the EWMA volatility model. sigma_EWMA represents the EWMA volatility estimate

title: EGARCH Model

notes: This equation defines the EGARCH model

title: GJR-GARCH Model
equation_latex: sigma_t^2 = omega + alpha * epsilon_{t-1}^2 + gamma * epsilon_{t-1}^2 * I(epsilon_{t-1} < 0) + beta * sigma_{t-1}^2
notes: This equation defines the GJR-GARCH model

title: Stochastic Volatility Model
equation_latex: dS_t = mu * S_t * dt + sqrt(v_t) * S_t * dW_t^S
notes: Advanced Topics - Volatility Modeling

title: Heston Correlation
notes: This equation defines the correlation between asset price and volatility shocks in the Heston model. rho represents the correlation coefficient

notes: This equation gives the implied volatility under the SABR model. sigma_BSM represents the Black-Scholes implied volatility

title: Dupire Formula
notes: Advanced Topics - Volatility Modeling

title: Poisson Process
notes: This equation defines the Poisson process for jump arrivals. N_t represents the number of jumps by time t

title: Poisson Process Probability
equation_latex: P(N_t = n) = exp(-lambda * t) * (lambda * t)^n / n!
notes: This equation gives the probability of n jumps occurring by time t. The Poisson distribution has mean lambda * t and variance lambda * t. The Poisson process is the standard model for discrete events like defaults or jumps in asset prices.

title: Compound Poisson Process
notes: This equation defines the compound Poisson process. X_t represents the accumulated jump size

title: Jump-Diffusion Model
equation_latex: dS_t = mu * S_t * dt + sigma * S_t * dW_t + S_t * dJ_t
notes: This equation defines the Merton jump-diffusion model. dS_t is the asset price change

title: Jump Component
notes: This equation defines the jump component in the jump-diffusion model. Y is the log jump size (typically normal)

title: Merton Jump-Diffusion Solution
equation_latex: S_t = S_0 * exp((mu - 0.5 * sigma^2 - lambda * (exp(mu_J + 0.5 * sigma_J^2) - 1)) * t + sigma * W_t + sum_{i=1}^{N_t} Y_i)
notes: This equation gives the solution to the Merton jump-diffusion SDE. S_t represents the asset price

title: Kou Double Exponential Jump Model
notes: This equation defines the Kou double exponential jump size distribution. Y_i represents the log jump size

title: Variance Gamma Process
notes: This equation defines the Variance Gamma (VG) process. X_t represents the log return

title: CGMY Process
notes: G * G_t))

title: Lévy Process
equation_latex: X_t = X_0 + mu * t + sigma * W_t + J_t
notes: This equation defines a general Lévy process. X_t represents the process value

title: Lévy Measure
notes: This equation defines the Lévy measure for jump processes. nu(dx) represents the intensity of jumps of size dx

title: Characteristic Function of Lévy Process
equation_latex: phi(u) = exp(i * u * mu * t - 0.5 * sigma^2 * u^2 * t + t * integral_{R} (exp(i * u * x) - 1 - i * u * x * I(|x| < 1)) * nu(dx))
notes: This equation defines the characteristic function of a Lévy process. phi(u) represents the characteristic function

title: Fourier Transform Option Pricing
equation_latex: C = exp(-r * T) * (1/2pi) * integral_{i * infinity}^{-i * infinity} exp(-i * u * ln(K)) * psi(u) / (i * u) du
notes: This equation defines option pricing using Fourier transform methods. C represents the call option price

title: Super-Replication Price
notes: This equation defines the super-replication price. V_super represents the minimum cost of a hedging strategy that dominates the payoff under all scenarios. In incomplete markets

title: Sub-Replication Price
notes: This equation defines the sub-replication price. V_sub represents the maximum value of a hedging strategy that is dominated by the payoff under all scenarios. Sub-replication provides a lower bound on the option price.

title: No-Arbitrage Price Interval
notes: This equation defines the no-arbitrage price interval in incomplete markets. The market price must lie between the sub-replication and super-replication prices. This interval can be wide in highly incomplete markets

title: Utility-Based Pricing
notes: This equation defines utility-based pricing. V represents the value maximizing expected utility U of consumption

title: Indifference Pricing
equation_latex: Indifference Price = E[U(W + payoff - price)] - E[U(W)]
notes: This equation defines the indifference price. The indifference price is the amount that makes the investor indifferent between holding the derivative and not holding it. Indifference pricing depends on the investor's utility function U and initial wealth W.

title: Entropy Risk Measure
notes: This equation defines the entropic risk measure. rho(X) represents the risk-adjusted value of the random payoff X

title: Convex Risk Measure
notes: This equation defines a convex risk measure. rho(X) represents the risk measure

title: Robust Optimization
notes: Advanced Topics - Incomplete Markets

title: Ambiguity Aversion
equation_latex: V = inf_{Q in Q} E_Q[payoff] + phi(Q)
notes: This equation defines pricing under model uncertainty (ambiguity aversion). V represents the value

title: Good-Deal Bounds
notes: This equation defines the good-deal bounds on the market price of risk theta. The bounds restrict the set of equivalent martingale measures to those that are not too extreme. Good-deal bounds narrow the no-arbitrage price interval by excluding unrealistic pricing measures.

title: Minimal Martingale Measure
notes: This equation defines the minimal martingale measure. The minimal martingale measure is the equivalent martingale measure that is closest to the physical measure in terms of relative entropy. It is used when the market price of risk is not uniquely defined.

title: Föllmer-Schweizer Decomposition
notes: This equation defines the Föllmer-Schweizer decomposition. X_t represents the discounted payoff

title: Mean-Variance Hedging
notes: This equation defines mean-variance hedging. The objective is to minimize the mean-squared hedging error between the payoff and the hedge portfolio. Mean-variance hedging is the optimal quadratic hedging strategy in incomplete markets.

title: Quadratic Hedging
notes: This equation defines quadratic hedging with a traded asset S_t and a residual value V_t. The hedge portfolio minimizes the mean-squared hedging error. Quadratic hedging is widely used when perfect hedging is impossible.

title: Market Price of Model Risk
notes: This equation defines the market price of model risk. lambda_model represents the Sharpe ratio of model risk

title: Model Uncertainty
notes: This equation incorporates model risk into pricing. V represents the risk-adjusted value

title: Deep Hedging
notes: This equation defines deep hedging using neural networks. Hedge_theta represents the hedging strategy parameterized by theta
